content.description:
Climb the "front"/trail-facing side of the boulder.  Start by working yourself down into the gap between the boulder and a small, half-buried block in front of it.  Get your feet down on little ledges just above the sludge bottom of this crevice.  Place your left hand on the arete and your right under a big, sloping undercling block.  Pull on and stretch (for reference, I'm 5'9") until you can get your left hand into a slot that's part of a large, long, rail.  Move up and right to finish.  There are two finishes.  Go to the right with the rail/ledge system for the easiest topout.  Going straight up is the same grade, but is more sustained, committing, and fun.  Excellent holds, moves, and features the whole way.



The "front"/trail-facing side of the boulder.

Blocky fall, but pads and a spotter can make it good.  Slipping on the first move is punished by a dip into bog sludge.

This triangular boulder has two faces and a sloping backside.  One face is pointed directly toward the trail.  This is the other face.  Climb the series of large ledges at the tallest part of this face.



The "left" face of the boulder/not the one facing the trail directly.

Clean fall.
One of the few truly freestanding boulders in Yellowknife.  It's mostly easy and is clearly really popular to scramble around with the hikers.
